title: Marcus - Back Pain Emergency Visit
learning_objectives: Recognize clinical deterioration requiring urgent reassessment
Identify new red flags that have developed since initial consultation
Practice continuity bridging in urgent/unscheduled context
Communicate need for escalation while maintaining patient trust
Apply MAAS follow-up adaptations in emergency setting

patient.name: Marcus
patient.appearance: Looks exhausted and in pain. Moving carefully. Clearly distressed. Dark circles under eyes from poor sleep.

personality.emotional_state: Frightened, frustrated, desperate for help. Pain has worn him down.
personality.notes: Was initially skeptical about medical care. Trusted the doctor after first visit but now feels let down because treatment didn't work. Worried something serious was missed. More willing to share concerns because situation is urgent.

previous_consultation.what_was_discussed: Marcus presented with lower back pain after lifting at work. Diagnosed as mechanical low back pain. No red flags identified at that time.
what_was_recommended: Take ibuprofen regularly (600mg three times daily with food)
Use ice for first 48 hours, then heat
Return if not improving in 1-2 weeks or if symptoms worsen
previous_consultation.what_patient_understood: It's a muscle thing, take painkillers, keep moving, should get better.
previous_consultation.follow_up_instructions: Return in 1-2 weeks, or sooner if pain worsens or new symptoms develop.

symptom_evolution.description: Pain initially seemed stable, then got significantly worse starting day 3. Now has new symptoms: pain radiating down left leg, some numbness in foot, difficulty with bladder.
new_symptoms: Radiating pain down left leg (started day 3)
Had one episode of near-incontinence this morning

medications.details: Took ibuprofen exactly as prescribed. Even set alarms to remember.

lifestyle_recommendations.details: Tried to stay active but pain got too bad. Has been mostly in bed last two days.
lifestyle_recommendations.barriers: Pain too severe to move normally

patient_experience.what_patient_researched: Googled 'back pain getting worse' and 'leg numbness with back pain'. Read about sciatica and herniated discs. Then read about cauda equina syndrome and got very scared.
new_concerns: Read that bladder problems with back pain can be serious
Worried something was missed at first visit
Worried about losing job if can't work
patient_experience.who_patient_talked_to: Girlfriend drove him here. She's in the waiting room, very worried.
patient_experience.coping: Barely sleeping, can't find comfortable position. Tried to tough it out but girlfriend insisted he come back today.

results.clinical_interpretation: This is NOT a results discussion visit. Patient is presenting with new symptoms suggesting possible cauda equina syndrome. Bladder symptoms + bilateral/progressive neurological symptoms are RED FLAGS requiring urgent evaluation.
results.how_to_explain: Not applicable - this is an emergency presentation requiring urgent workup, not a results follow-up.

prognosis.expected_course: Depends on diagnosis. If cauda equina syndrome confirmed, requires emergency MRI and possible urgent surgery. Delay can result in permanent neurological damage.
factors_favoring_recovery: Came in promptly when symptoms changed
Symptoms still relatively new (early intervention possible)
prognosis.what_patient_should_expect: Will need urgent imaging today. May need to go to hospital.
prognosis.when_to_worry: This IS the 'when to worry' situation. Bladder symptoms with back pain and leg weakness require immediate attention.

today.stated_reason: The pain got worse and now my leg is numb
today.real_reason: Terrified something serious was missed, especially after reading about cauda equina
today.hidden_agenda: Wants reassurance but also validation that something is really wrong - tired of feeling dismissed

new_concerns: What if he can't walk properly again?
Was something missed at the first visit?

interval_emotions.what_patient_felt: Started hopeful, got increasingly scared as pain worsened and new symptoms appeared. Felt alone in his suffering.
interval_emotions.unresolved_from_last_time: Never fully understood why back pain happens or what the warning signs are

complaint.chief_complaint: Back pain got much worse and now my leg is numb and I'm having trouble peeing

heuristic_1_nature.description: Deep, severe pain in lower back that now shoots down left leg
heuristic_1_nature.quality: Sharp shooting pain (radicular) on top of dull constant ache
heuristic_1_nature.location: Lower back, now also left buttock and down back of left leg to foot
heuristic_1_nature.radiation: Down left leg to foot - follows clear dermatomal pattern

heuristic_2_time_intensity.onset_description: Back pain started 5 days ago after lifting. Leg symptoms started day 3, getting progressively worse.
heuristic_2_time_intensity.duration: Constant now, with sharp shooting episodes

ideas_concerns_expectations.patient_ideas: Read about herniated disc and cauda equina syndrome. Thinks something is seriously wrong with his spine.
ideas_concerns_expectations.patient_concerns: Terrified about permanent nerve damage, paralysis, surgery, losing job, never being the same
ideas_concerns_expectations.patient_expectations: Wants to be taken seriously, wants answers today, wants pain relief, wants to know he won't be permanently damaged

present: Progressive neurological deficit (leg weakness and numbness)
Pain not responding to appropriate treatment
red_flags.notes: URGENT: This presentation has multiple red flags for cauda equina syndrome. Requires immediate evaluation with MRI. Do not reassure or send home without proper workup.

diagnosis.working_diagnosis: Suspected cauda equina syndrome / large disc herniation with neurological compromise
differential: Large lumbar disc herniation with radiculopathy
key_findings: Failure to improve with conservative treatment

simulation_guidance.initial_presentation: Comes in walking slowly and stiffly, clearly in pain. Sits down carefully on edge of chair. Looks tired and scared. May say 'The pain got way worse, doc, and now I can't feel my foot properly.' Urgency in his voice.

freely_shared: Took all the medication as prescribed
if_asked_directly: Leg feels weak, not just numb
Can't walk on his heels properly
if_asked_sensitively: Feels like he wasn't taken seriously the first time
Worried about losing his job and relationship
Feels guilty for not coming sooner
will_not_share: Won't volunteer the incontinence unless asked directly (embarrassed)
Won't admit how scared he really is without empathy shown first
Won't discuss job/relationship fears without trust

emotional_moments: When asked about bladder function (embarrassed, scared)
When told this needs urgent investigation (validation mixed with fear)
When discussing what could have been done differently
guardrails: Stay in character as frightened young man
Show pain throughout - shift position, wince
Express frustration appropriately if not taken seriously
Do not use medical terminology beyond what he read online
React realistically to news of hospital admission/MRI

what_patient_remembers: Doctor said it was probably muscular
Come back if it gets worse
Something about not staying in bed
what_patient_forgot: Specific warning signs to watch for

freely_admits: Took all the medication on time
Tried to stay active at first
if_asked_directly: Had to stop activity because pain too bad
Has been mostly in bed last 2 days
if_asked_sensitively: Feels guilty for not coming in sooner
Girlfriend pushed him to come today
will_not_volunteer: The embarrassing bladder symptoms without direct questioning

key_items: A.2 — Bridge to previous encounter despite urgency
2.5-2.8 — Red flag screening (critical in this case)
B.5 — Respond to fear and validate concerns
B.7 — Address feeling of being dismissed
3.11 — Explain escalation and next steps clearly
maas_focus.learning_notes: This case teaches recognition of clinical deterioration. Student must bridge continuity (acknowledge previous visit), but quickly pivot to urgent reassessment. Key challenge is validating patient's concerns while efficiently gathering red flag information. Student should NOT offer reassurance until proper evaluation completed. Tests MAAS items on red flag screening (2.5-2.8) in a realistic deterioration scenario.

items: A.2 (bridging) — 'I saw you five days ago, tell me what's happened since'
2.5-2.8 (red flag screening) — Systematic check of neurological symptoms
B.5/B.7 (validate concerns) — 'I can see this has been frightening for you'
3.11 (next steps) — 'Given these new symptoms, we need to act quickly'
